ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lectures with live virtual discussions with the professor and TAs

Professor Ngan prerecorded lectures for students to watch before Thursday's section discussion. During Tuesday's lecture, Professor Ngan would briefly reference his prerecorded lectures, but he would mostly use that opportunity to go through exercises examining art pieces and inviting students to actively participate in sharing their thoughts and reactions.
recorded lectures and discussion sections
The class was a live virtual lecture on Tuesdays and a long live virtual discussion section on Thursdays.
recorded lecture + live virtual lecture + virtual discussion sections
We had in person lecture/discussions with the professor on Tuesday and then section with the TF on Thursday. We watched pre-recorded lectures each week as well.
Combination of recorded lecture and virtual seminar.
The class was composed of two central parts: 1) weekly recorded lecture(s), and 2) virtual seminars focused on lecture information and/or readings.
Pre-recorded lectures

Recorded lecture, live virtual lecture, and virtual seminar class
Recorded lectures on Saturdays, live virtual lectures on Tuesdays, and virtual seminars on Thursdays
Live virtual lecture, asynchronous lecture, synchronous section

live zoom & section
pre-recorded lecture

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: overview of Asian art history and the ability to think critically about objects from different time periods and cultures
I gained a more than adequate introduction to the rich art history of Korea, China, India, and Japan.
I've gained an overview of Asian art history and methods of analyzing art works. I also learnt how the use of different materials sometimes complements the purpose of an art work.
You get a wonderful survey of Asian art, touching upon Korea, China, Japan, and India and a focus on the transregional connections.
I explored how creative solutions define and influence East Asian society and how to closely analyze artistic works (in terms of historical context and otherwise).

Great introductory course to Asian art and culture across a span of countries and centuries - the course was both expansive and went in-depth. Additionally, this course helped me Develop my writing skills and visual analysis skills.
I got a good intro to Asian art history, not just ancient but contemporary as well
Asian art and culture

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We covered a lot of time and geography in terms of art from China, Japan, Korea, and India throughout ancient history. I do wish we spent more time with more modern art rather than in ancient art, or that we looked at more pieces of art rather than focusing on only a few pieces per lecture.

One strength of this course was the introduction to the diverse art traditions of Asia; however, that was also a limitation because a survey course like this didn't have the time to touch upon the art of other Asian regions like Central or Southeast Asia. With that being said, the course overall succeeded in providing a general survey to Asian art history.
The topics covered in this course are very engaging. I also enjoyed lectures given by the guest speakers a lot.

Strength: the three types of learning methods combined (recorded lectures + live lectures + discussion sections) facilitate learning to the best extent possible during covid
Weakness: we didn't have much time to go deeper into any of the areas introduced, due to the capacity of the course content (being an introductory level course)

The strengths lie in the teaching. Professor Ngan was always so kind during office hours. I went several times over the course of the semester and he always gave me additional material to supplement my learning and kind advice on best practices for the exam. Nicole, my TF, was also very kind and always met with me for extra meetings to go over papers and the midterm. 

I found it very helpful that there were optional, challenging readings for us to push ourselves. I think what could be helpful in keeping track of the overall narrative could be a posted timeline and some additional survey readings for background knowledge. I would also appreciate a list of all the art works we learned about or saw through the lectures or sections. 

But, I can't emphasize this enough, this course was absolutely wonderful and was a bright spot in my week! Professor Ngan's enthusiasm and care for the students really shows. He helped me brainstorm ideas for the exhibition proposal assignment, helping me think about themes about the peony motif in art!
A significant strength: the teaching fellows, and their high level of involvement and engagement with their students.

I enjoyed the combination of synchronous and asynchronous activities. The format of the course was designed well to facilitate student learning, and all of the readings were informative. Professor and TFs were all enthusiastic and engaging. Another strength of the course was the discussion style of the lectures; I appreciated getting the chance to share my thoughts and listening to my classmates' opinions!
Quincy is great! Having live lectures and asynchronous lectures and sections was kind of a lot though

Graded was very variable by section, I know I was penalized by my TA for things either not on rubrics/expectations set by the professor that students in other sections where not penalized for which was pretty frusterating.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The prerecorded lectures succeeded in allowing students living in disparate time zones to learn at their own pace. I also appreciated how the instructor did not make turning on our Zoom cameras in class mandatory. That was very gracious of him since it gave students the benefit of the doubt if they weren't feeling too well on a particular day.

I think the prerecorded lectures are quite informative and offers a comprehensive summary of the weekly topics. They are very effective in providing background knowledge that is necessary for the discussions.
the three types of learning methods combined (recorded lectures + live lectures + discussion sections) facilitate learning to the best extent possible during covid

I think the pre-recorded lectures and quizzes were effective given the circumstances. I really enjoyed them! I think I just wanted even more information on art historical topics we didn't have time to cover!

I thought that Professor Ngan did a great job of keeping students engaged through remote learning. I especially thought that his weekly pre-recorded lectures were helpful and informative, and aided in our understanding of concepts discussed in live lectures and sections.
Quincy did a great job with zoom, the presentations were fun and engaging and I liked that we could write on the art images

Thursday "lectures" where really just section meetings, and as such they probably should have been shortened. Section sizes where uneven, so my 4 person section often was left scrounging for material for the whole 75 minutes.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you are very interested in Asian art in particular. If you are looking for an introduction to art history, I think there may be more engaging art history courses.

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in gaining an introduction to Asian art history. Since I came into the class having never taken an art history course, I always learned something new. A big motivation for me in taking this course was the addition of Korea as one of the regions of study. Since I already have a passion for Korean studies, looking at Korea through art was a special privilege. I would only add that while doing the weekly readings does not always directly pertain to the prerecorded lecture material, it provides useful context and facilitates section discussions.

I would recommend this course, because it is a solid introductory course for someone interested in Asian art history. I've loved all of the topics covered. The readings aren't really heavy and are fun to read.
Yes. A good fifth credit if you're into Asian art - pretty fun and not too much work

I would recommend this class to anyone, even those who have never taken an art history or East Asian studies course before. It's a wonderful survey that covers both ancient and contemporary art and I really believe you learn a lot of visual analysis skills.

If you have any interest in East Asian culture or in Art History I highly recommend this course! Quincy has organized this class to a T and it makes it so easy and engaging to learn this material. I particularly like that he used the Thursday class meeting as a section rather than adding an extra hour outside of class which is incredibly kind and considerate of our time as busy students. The use of a recorded lecture to supplement our meetings is a perfect example of how tech can be accommodated for remote teaching. If you put in effort, Quincy and the TFs are prepared to help you pass the course since the focus is on learning the material rather than on strict grading.
Absolutely - I felt intellectually challenged and engaged.

Yes! This class offers a great introduction to Asian art and culture, and art history skills and concepts more generally. It is a great course for both art history majors and non-majors to take, as the class incorporates knowledge and skills from, and is applicable to, different subjects.
Sure if you want an easy class and are interested in Asian art
If you are new to art history or Asian art this course is a great introduction. The workload is fairly low and the material is very interesting. Professor Ngan is an incredible professor.
The subject material was interesting, I think the course could be performed with more uniform expectations for tsudents.
